Award.AwardTitle: PEERS Exploring Biology, Mathematics and Statistics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Department of Biology is collaborating with the Department of Mathematics & Statistics at Sam Houston State University to continue their prior S-STEM project. The project is selecting 9 students from the freshman or sophomore classes, 9 students from combined junior and senior classes, and 9 graduate students each of the four years, to received scholarships of $3,000, $6,000 or $7,250 respectively. These scholarships are proving to be effective in enabling students to complete degree programs in a timely manner by allowing the students to reduce their work-for-pay hours. The students are using this 'extra time' to enrich their education through interdisciplinary experiences including research, mentoring, and professional development. The program is aligned with the workforce needs both in the region and nationally. To ensure student success, PEERS offers scholars a number of services including: mentoring from faculty, graduate students, and industry representatives; ad hoc tutoring; professional development seminars; welcome activities; participation in both a local and a national meeting; and access to additional support services.

The project is building on effective practices learned in the prior project that demonstrated the value of increased attention to mentoring, tutoring by more advanced students, the value for career development opportunities, explicit attention to community building, and interdisciplinary undergraduate research experiences. Recognizing increased need with the biotechnology area, the PEERS program is focussing on the intersection of biomathematics and biostatistics.

As 35% of SHSU students are members of an underrepresented group, and the majors in the STEM disciplines at SHSU are at least as diverse, the project is succeeding at broadening the participation of such groups in the STEM workforce. Through their deliberate and calculated actions, the project is also succeeding at increasing the numbers of scholars transitioning to graduate school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Departments of Biology and Mathematics & Statistics at Sam Houston State University collaborated to build upon and strengthen the highly successful PEERS scholarship program. PEERS I and II functioned synergistically with other research and development programs to increase enrollment in both undergraduate and graduate levels of study, particularly first-generation students and those from underrepresented populations. The goal of PEERS II was to continue increasing the number of well-educated and skilled employees in technical areas of regional and national need. Associated objectives were: to increase retention of students pursuing degrees in participating disciplines; to increase the number of students from underrepresented groups that complete degrees in participating disciplines; and to improve the transition of students to graduate study or employment. Special program features included tutoring services; peer, faculty and industry mentors; social events; and professional development opportunities.

 

PEERS II broadened the participation of underrepresented groups by targeting recruitment efforts toward SHSU’s significant minority and first-generation college student populations, encouraging them to pursue STEM majors. PEERS II supported 61 students with 65 scholarships worth $564,982, as well as travel funds and tutoring support. Seventy-seven percent of PEERS scholars have graduated or will graduate within one year. Of the PEERS graduates, at least 74% of undergraduates and 86% of graduate students transitioned into further STEM graduate studies or STEM employment. Approximately 60% of PEERS II scholars were first-generation college students. Approximately 31% were underrepresented minorities, while 65% were female.


PEERS II was designed to equip future scientists with the educational foundation for solving complex interdisciplinary problems, through published interdisciplinary research by both students and faculty. Seventy percent of scholars reported conducting independent research. Interdisciplinary research between biologists and mathematicians/statisticians represented at least six presentations and publications by PEERS scholars. These relationships also created further collaborations for non-PEERS students and faculty.

 According to exit surveys, 90% of PEERS scholars indicated that the scholarship reduced their financial worries, enabled them to spend fewer hours working, and reduced the amount of student loans they received. Eighty-three percent of scholars indicated that the PEERS increased their self-confidence, while 100% indicated that the PEERS scholarship had positive impacts on their academic careers. Sixty-three percent of the recipients indicated that he/she made contacts that may result or resulted in employment or graduate school; 75% indicated they made contacts that may result or resulted in research projects; and 77.5% indicated they formed a lasting relationship with at least one faculty advisor.
